Amazing.* A very fantastic potatoes stand reminiscent of the famous one at the Houston Rodeo.* For some reason, we spent 15 minutes at the soaps stand.* Brats or something like it. Really, any grilled meat + bun stand.* Waffles/crepes for dessert.* Perfect picture opportunities at the west end.

From Mid November until the beginning of January you will find this giant Christmas Market between the Place de la Concorde and Place Charles-de-Gaulle hard to miss right on the  Avenue des Champs-Élysées. It features over 200 white, wooden stands, countless carousels for children - and a tacky santa´s sled flying over (a part of) the market every hour or so. The city of Paris claims 15 Million visitors for the market during the 7 weeks it´s open - which I totally believe when I look at the crowds getting their fill of sausage and hot wine in the evening.I´ve been there now two years in a row and what I liked a lot about this Christmas Market were the stands that are sort of in the second row. The real artisanal stands in the 'Village des Artisans d´Art' or the 'Village Gourmand' featuring regional food-stands. There are also plenty of activities and rides for children.What I don´t really like is the sort of "first row". The stands seem to repeat themselves every couple of hundred meters and mostly are the very generic type of christmas market stands. In between there are also your generic paris-souvenir stands - which basically have no christmas-themed goods to offer and stick out like a sore thumb. All in all, the Champs-Élysées Christmas Market strikes me to be more of a fair/fun fair than what I consider a christmas market. It simply lacks cosieness. Paris also has a lot of smaller Christmas Markets (basically in all  the Arrondissements at some point of time), if you´re looking for the real cozy christmas feeling - you may wanna look into those.If you´re just looking for a huge, overrun fair in Winter - nothing wrong with the 'Marché de Noël des Champs-Elysées'.

Each time I go to France, I love exploring different regions and neighborhood.  This time, we rented a beautiful 2 bedroom apartment in the Bellville area.Exploring the area, I found this gem of a Parc.  I love exploring where the locals go for relaxation and where they eat.  After a tasty meal nearby, my friend Mats flew in from London and we explored this lovely park.  We mostly stayed under the tree lined paths because it was a hot day.  For a park, we were here on a Wednesday around 2pm, lots of people looking like they are having a siesta or a break from work.  Everyone seemed friendly, kept to themselves.  The park is rich with different plants, trees and flowers.  We hiked up to the highest point, from here you have an observation look out on the rooftops of Paris and a gorgeous view of Sacre Coeur.  On the way to the top, you get to cross a bridge and below is a little lake.  Some parts are rather steep, go at your own pace and bring a bottled water on a hot day and a plus if you wear a hat.Every turn you go into this park had something appealing.If you look at my images, there is also a cave.  During raining season, the cave has a waterfall in it, it's very pretty.Plenty of grass room to have a picnic, take a nap or read a book.  If you opt for something else, lots of park benches that faces the lake.A wonderful oasis in the heart of Paris.  Everyone is welcome here, singles, couples, children, dogs...

There are much more locals than tourists here. The park (opened in 1867) is really beautiful but it is less popular among visitors comparing to top Paris attractions. This is exactly why it's worth a visit - add something a bit different to your Paris trip. Landscape design is outstanding - you will find an artificial lake, a grotto and waterfalls. One of the two bridges was designed by Gustave Eiffel.The park is hilly and you can enjoy amazing views of Paris from different points. One of the highest points is Temple de la Sibylle (50m above the lake). You can see Basilique du Sacré-Cœur de Montmartre from here.This place is great for running - you can do flat circles around the lake or hilly runs everywhere, there are some 8 kilometers of roads and paths.One of the three restaurants, Rosa Bonheur, is really popular, it may take an hour of waiting to get in on weekends.You can find 5 areas with free Wi-Fi in the park. Post to yelp from here and don't forget to FUC (funny/useful/cool) this review :)P.S. There's a renovation going on in the park from 2013 till 2016, some areas may be closed (Temple de la Sibylle is closed at the time of writing).

A bit off the beaten track but easily accessible via the Paris Metro, this park is beautiful. Built into an old quarrey, the park is immaculately landscaped.Great vantage points, locals sunning themselves, children playing, joggers racing by...this place is filled with locals.We stopped for an ice cream cone and wandered the grounds in awe.We're  very happy we made the trip out....it was well worth the $3.80€ (for 1 way for 2 ppl) on the subway.Neighborhood surrounding the park isn't anything special, but the park is.

The first time I visited the park, I was taken by surprise as the parc consist of many things. It has a bridge which had an epic view of the park. There was a small island and it was very tranquil. I love this park as it had many beautiful sceneries! Amazing for a picnic with friends!

Gorgeous - what a total surprise. The topography is so unexpected. I entered the park for a run and had no idea what treasures awaited me. There is a wide path which circumnavigates the park. I passed multiple restrooms which can be helpful while on a run or exploring the city. There is a cafe in the park also- nice if you need some refreshments. The paved path has quite a bit of elevation change, and looking inward to the center of the park I was amazed by the serious drop offs! Further around and I saw the lake appear with the temple perched high above it and knew I needed to go up there. A bridge crosses high over the lake and one can climb the path to the temple. Beautiful views reward you for the climb. Sacre Coeur in the distance. There are other areas near the park with slightly better views of the city (Parc de Belleville for one) but this one isn't bad and it's a much more beautiful park by far. Ah, Paris can delight you in so many ways and this park is a fantastic surprise.

The park offers beautiful views of the city. Grassy knolls for lounging. Fresh fruit vendors at metro entry by park entry. One evening there was a concert during our visit. Great running trails as well.

This was my favorite park that we visited. It had some good hills and scenic views and bridges.  I'm glad we decided to walk back to our hotel in Pantin from the city, otherwise we would not have stumbled on it.The park wasn't crowded and it looked like a locals' park.
Such a beautiful spot that it is always crowded as soon as the weather is nice.My favorite thing to do is probably to go there with a bottle of wine and some friends and just sit and enjoy the sight.

A nice park.plenty of walking or running trails, you see many groups doing Tai Chi or Yoga, loads of interesting nooks & crannies and some vantage points for views of the city including Montmartre & the Sacre Ceour.
Im from NY and didn't expect the parks in Paris to he so beautiful ! I honestly recommend this location it was great.

This is such a cute little shopping park!  We found it by accident bc we had to ride the metro here to catch our small bus for our day trip to Fontainebleau and Vaux-Le-Vicomte, otherwise, we'd never have ventured this far. When we returned in the evening, it was bustling with people shopping and eating and sitting outside on the patios enjoying drinks and desserts. Several stores selling jewelry, women's clothing, fragrance, electronics and clothes and other gifts were open as well as a ton of restaurants and cafes of all kinds. It's an easy metro ride so I highly recommend it.  We already had dinner plans so we only spent about an hour walking around and browsing but we might come back for dinner and explore more next time we are in town.

A cute shopping center close to the Cour Saint-Emilion subway stop. This area has a ton of various stores, cool art installations, and a cinema next door. If you're visiting France from elsewhere I wouldn't say this is worthy of a visit in of itself since there's so many other great areas of Paris to explore but if you find yourself in the area it's worth a short stop.

My sister and I stayed at a nearby hotel on our stay to Paris.  After we checked in we were hungry so we decided to venture out and look for somewhere to eat.  The front desk person at our hotel mentioned there was a lot of restaurants down the street so we headed off.  We ended up in Bercy Village and fell in love with it.  This shopping area has a decent amount a restaurants, a bakery, stores to shop at as well as a gym and theater.  I fell in love with the Italian restaurant Vapiano.  I have been dreaming about that pasta since I left Paris. I really enjoyed visting Eric Kayser.  They offer some delicious desserts as well as breads, drinks, fruit, sandwiches, and ice cream. The most crowded place I saw was Five Guys.  The lines were ridiculously long around that restaurant.  There was an awesome kitchen store that had a variety of items and there were multiple clothing shops.  It is a very nice area to walk around and explore.Another great thing about Bercy Village is that it's located very close to the metro.  Everything was very accessible from Bercy Village.  If I ever return to Paris I would not mind staying in this area again.  I thought it was wonderful.

I completely fell in love with the Bercy Village area.  We found a hotel, the Kyriad for a great price in this area.  It was close enough to the Metro station and near enough to the city center.  After we checked into our hotel we decided to go for a walk.  It is only about a 5 minute walk down some small streets to Bercy Village.  There is so much in this little area to keep your attention.  We found some great restaurants, my favorite being an Italian restaurant called Vapiano Cour Saint-Emillion.  There are all kinds of restaurants, fast food places, bakeries, and dessert stops.  The village also has some clothing stores, kitchenware stores and other little stores.  There is also a gym and theater.  The village is about a 5 minute walk from the metro station. It is easy to hop on and off.  I found Bercy Village to be a lively at night, calm in the day and a great place to stroll if you just want to walk around.  I would definitely return to Bercy Village if in Paris again.

Not really worth the trip out there unless you're a local looking for a movie, specific shopping items or maybe to grab a bite.  It's like going to Woodbury commons but with not many options and brands that are readily available in the states. There are a bunch of restaurants but nothing special.  The park near by the village is nice though. Otherwise skip the trip out there as a tourist.. It was my 6th time out to Paris and I had a day with nothing to do so made the trek.. was totally underwhelmed.

Pretty chill shopping center/restaurant area in the middle of Paris. You pretty much find everything you need here for an outing - plenty of restaurants, bars, a huge UGC cinema, a gym, some shops...what more could u want? Obviously if ur coming here for shopping, u may not find everything u need, but they do have a Sephora :) other than that, we have a "cheesecake and co", frog pub, CMG sports club, and soon a 5 guys burger and fries - yum. They put that delish burger joint right next to the gym - no chill hahahaha. They wrong for that one! But anywho, cool spot, easily accessible on line 14 and nice park nearby.

Very surprised! what a nice neighborhood Bercy was. We visited the village and had a fabulous lunch then by mistake we found the old winery garden. We spent over an hour strolling around the garden, delightful.
A really cool place in Paris to have a drink, go to cinema , in a restaurant or simply hang out in the shopsI recommand the shop Album

Ew. Shopping here is on par with a big American strip mall. None of the stores are anything you can't find elsewhere in Paris and it's not near anything interesting except the lovely Bercy park and neighboring movie theater. I recommend staying away from the restaurants as well - they looked overpriced and mediocre.

this place was my hood for 5 days! It had everything you could possibly need as a tourist. A grocery store, clothing and department store all in one (mono prix), various pastry shops and coffee place and tons of restaurants!

It's a MUST DO while you're in Paris!! It was our family first trip to Paris. Xavier was very accommodating to all of our requests, even the last minute booking!! Francois was our tour guide. He was wonderful! He showed us a GRAND time around Paris. We only had 3 days in Paris and the scooter tour gave us a taste of all the beautiful landmarks. We love Francois so much we decided to tour the next 2 days with him by foot. He was able to take us to all the places we wanted to go to and more!! He took us to the best ice cream place in Paris! You can bank on that. He was very knowledgeable, kind and patience. He has great photography skill so you're guaranteed to have great photos in Paris. He's also a foodie so he'll show you all the best places to eat in Paris, like a local. He saved us so much time and trouble. You will not regret your time with him. My family loved Francois so much they invited him to visit them in the States! Lol.

My girlfriend and I did the scooter tour today. Lucas was our guide and we had a great day. Tons of fun, we got to see so many different things, I think it's the best way to see Paris as you can cover so much ground so quickly and parking is super easy.We stopped a couple of times for coffee, had some lunch, all in all a solid days entertainment. Special thanks to Lucas, super nice, informative and really funny. We had a blast hanging with him, it was like hanging with a friend.

My husband decided to book the tour to Versailles. At first I was very hesitantthinking that it would be too dangerous. However, I am glad he went ahead and booked the tour. It was the most memoriable experience we had on our whole trip in Paris. Xavier was so friendly and nice. We had another couple with our tour and Xavier was able to make everyone's request happen. We couldn't ask for a better tour guide.  It really is a must do!!! Don't miss out on your chance of a life time, book now I highly recommend Paris by Scooter.

Great trip! Milian was an excellent tour guide. We took the scooter tour our first afternoon in Paris. It really gave us the lay of the land and the ability to see most of the attractions we wanted to see in a short period of time.I 100% recommend this!

We booked a last minute Vespa Tour of Versailles and could not have been more pleased with our adventure. From our first encounter with Milan, we knew we were in good hands and that it would be a memorable tour.Milan showed us parts on Paris and outer areas we would have never considered exploring. Outside of showing us the major Versailles attractions and explaining their significance, he helped us with photography and even provided a few tips to improve our struggling French.We learned more about France over a long lunch with Milan than through our travel guide. Exploring and discovering is more than reading facts. Getting the heartbeat of a place has a much larger impact on travelers and Milan and Paris by Scooter does this well.This is a must do while in Paris. If we would have had more time, we would have booked another one of the Paris by Scooter tours and requested Milan as our guide. It was one of our favorite things to do in France.Tour on September 4th, 2015
We had an amazing time, this is by far the best way to see paris! The owner of the shop was nice and helpful. Next time in Paris i will stop here first for another vespa!

My boyfriend and I decided to visit Paris last minute on our European vacation and didn't know the best way to see the city.... That's when we stumbled upon the other TripAdvisor reviews of the "Paris by Scooter" attraction... And we were not disappointed!!! Our tour guide, Milan, was fantastic. He was extremely knowledgeable about Paris and, outside of your typical tour guide, was able to offer really interesting information that we otherwise wouldn't have been able to receive! This tour was able to show us every major landmark in Paris and even some of the "not-so-famous" attractions as well. I will admit, I was hesitant to ride through the Parisian traffic, especially around L'Arc de Triomphe, but he was such a good driver/guide (as was my boyfriend) that my anxiety quickly faded away! This is a safe, fun, and once-in-a-lifetime experience that I would recommend to anyone traveling around Paris. Also, the service was extremely convenient - they offered to drop the scooters off right at our hotel room (we opted to meet them at their shop for our own poor planning, which is also an option)! They are SO accommodating. Keep in mind it does cost you a good chunk of change, but to us, it was worth every penny. If we go back, we would 110% take the longer tour into Versailles and even rent the scooter for another day of travel on our own. If you get nothing out of this review, let it be this, YOU WILL NOT BE DISAPPOINTED SEEING PARIS BY VESPA!
Xavier is legit! I have known him for ever and trust me he won't show you the normal tourist route. Why don't they do the same here in SF? I don't know... His tour is the bomb.

What an amazing experience!! Xavier took my husband and I around Paris - exploring places we would have never thought to check out on our own. I got the privilege of riding on the back so I was able to take pictures and enjoy the ride. I would definitely recommend this tour to anyone wanting to experience Paris!!!

Xavier provided a great service! He arrived with two scooters and all the necessary riding gear on time. He was friendly and knowledgable. My wife and I had a blast riding scooters around Paris with him. He  showed us a whole bunch of sites that we otherwise wouldn't have seen on our own. Honestly, I had so much fun that it makes me want to start a scooter tour business. :) Thanks Xavier!
The reviews made this sound a lot larger than it was. There weren't many shops and half weren't open when we went. It's a pretty building but it's not quite like the descriptions.

One of the most special places in all of Paris!Now with the addition of new restaurants it's even more special than ever before, great shops, great food, relaxing, Paris at its very best.Stroll throughout and stop in and visit a few boutiques and then decide your food option and follow with an afternoon drink, just a perfect lunch destination!Perfect!

Galerie Viviene was built in 1823 and is registered as a historical monument. Located near the Bourse (the stock exchange), the Bank of France, Palais-Royal, and behind Bibliothèque Richelieu. The entrance on Rue des Petits-Champs of this iconic covered arcade is gorgeous along with a spectacular mosaic created by a 19th century artist.  The décor was influenced by Pompeii. Boutiques, book stores, and cafes are located inside. Opening times of shops are usually 08:30-20:30.

Beautiful to stroll through if in the area. I wouldn't necessarily seek it out, but if in the area, it is stunning to see. We were on our way to the Opera House and stumbled upon it.Some stores were a bit expensive, some were reasonable.Great place to stroll if caught in a Paris rainstorm.
Enjoyed the art work. It's difficult to take pictures. Lots of walking. The area has some neat shops.
One of the more elegant vintage shopping arcades in Paris.With restaurants, high end shops.
Beautiful interior design, however nothing was open and I went during a weekday during work hours. Quite disappointing.

I also bought a large designer bowl with silk red flowers in a gel setting.  It is milky in color, not clear at all.  I still love the Art Work but think Emilio Robba should replace my bowl and use this experience as a learning experience on the product that  is used to hold these silky flowers in place is not working.  I do not no how to get someone to assist .   That was about $300 down the drain. Olivia

You have to see it to believe it. Locks on locks on locks! Now they have had a few problems with all the locks being attached to bridges and particularly this one. Caution, don't be fooled by the other "lock bridge" imposters. A lot of other bridges in the area have been conscripted to take the load off this one. I doubt if it's going to cave anytime soon. We took the smallest lock I could find(trying to do my part to lighten the load) and attached it to another lock.It's a fun thing to do and I figure they have engineers calculating the load. So it's still legal and people are continuing to place their lock on the bridge. I say go for it!The bridge is practically in the shadow of Notre Dame which made it even more enticing. I felt like I was staking out my small patch of Paris. My claim over the Seine River!
We couldn't go to Paris and miss out on the Lover's Bridge. Most known for all the locks people put on the bridge. However, sadly the locks due get removed after a while because they get too heavy.

Fun fact: with 37 other unique bridges that connect the left to the right banks over the Siene river, what sets this bridge apart from others is it being the infamously  "LoVE Lock" bridge. This is where lovers come to place their personally inscribed lock that they chose to place professing their love to those that visit this bridge. Couples then choose to throw the keys into the river so that their love can last forever!  While it seems romantic and harmless, Parisians and environmentalist hate the idea that people come from all over the world to practice this love ritual. There were once so many locks that the bridge actually buckled under the sheer weight of the combined love locks. It was told the locks were all cut off but luckily we found it still intact.  .  Luckily for others, there's another bridge down aways that have ample amounts of room for more locks to be added, that is... if being romantic is your thing. If you're a Parisian or environmentalist then you can help by cutting down the locks once the couple leaves. Or better yet, I was told there are some people who have master keys that unlock the ones without inscriptions on them, only to resell them to tourists Great money maker ideas I tell you.

RIPWhat once was filled with years of love is no longer.. they have taken off the fence lining the bridge filled with locks of love and replaced it with a glass or plexiglass panel that makes it impossible to lock anything on.Sad this spot is no longer here

I came here during my visit to France and realized how stupid people are. These locks are tearing down the bridges in Paris because they are heavy and rusting through the city! People need to stop doing this! these locks do not lock anybody's love in! it's so ridiculous! The city goes through and cut off all the locks every week anyway so people's love lock get broken. I guess all y'all are getting a divorceDo the environment and next generation a favor, stop locking the bridges! The city have made several attempts to prevent people from locking these locks. They put in plastic boards across the bridge and yet people somehow still found ways to put locks in the bridge. They buy bigger locks to fit around the top medal part of the bridge that was too wide for the regular sized locks. People are so selfish. "I want to represent my love" "I want to keep my love lock in" it's always I, I. What I want to do. Have you ever thought about the city?

Bringing new meaning to love lockdown (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HZwMX6T5Jhk&feature=kp)Can't believe we missed this on our first trip to Paris. So, when we had a 24 hour layover in Paris on our way back from Amsterdam we knew we had to hit up the Pont De l'Archeveche - with our engraved locks in tow.After browsing the outside of Notre Dame, we walked over to the bridge. I was expecting to see a lot of locks but this was insane. They had massive locks hooked on to the railings, with rows and rows of smaller locks attached to those. It was literally a sea of locks, all shapes, all different materials, with different writings and colors. At the risk of getting too deep here, it was all these locks - all these different looking locks - representing all these different couples - different looking couples. It was truly beautiful.You can spend a good amount of time looking through the locks. From the absolutely absurd giant-locks (which I assume were used to close the gates to a castle, because there can't be any other reason for them to exist) to the regular pad locks of all sizes.The bridge will be busy with love birds, clipping their locks, tossing their keys in the water (what? you aren't allowed to? Oh, yea, we didn't...wink-wink). You might see some folks making out hardcore as well. If you aren't into extreme PDA, you will feel utterly uncomfortable here.Really cool to leave a little piece of "us" back in Paris and we will go back and see if it's still there in a few years!

I heard that the love locks from the Paris Bridge were removed last year in June, due to the dangerous weight, so you can imagine how surprised I was when we came across the railings on the riverside, near the bridge, that still had some metal locks on them. The array of multi-colored locks was definitely artsy, so I couldn't help but admire the charming symbolism for a few minutes. According to tradition, couples put metal locks on the bridge to signify their concrete love for each other and then they would throw the keys to the Seine River below. Ooh am I friggen sucker for romance! I only wish we got to 'seal our love' on the bridge to commemorate our honeymoon. Stop by for what's left of this fascinating attraction--don't forget to bring a lock while they still permit people to place locks on the railings :)

Pont de L'archevêché is one of Paris' most recognizable lock bridges.Located just beside Notre Dame Cathedral, you can't miss it. The inner romantic in me loves lock bridges, even though i know they're being gradually removed- I'm hoping the removed panels end up in the Pompadou Centre, as they're beautiful, and basically immersive modern art - but i somehow doubt it. The locks on this bridge haven't been removed yet- if you're over at Notre Dame, be sure to visit here (and Kilometre Zero - see other review).Look out for the sculpted head on the bridge- it's kinda creepy!
Another bridge were the locks have been removed.  It's still a wonderful bridge to get amazing views, but be noticed, NO LOVE LOCKS.

There are many love lock bridges in Paris, this particular one is behind Notre Dame. If you take a walk down the side of the cathedral between the gardens and the Seine, this is the first bridge you will come to.I didn't put a lock on the bridge personally, but I have a lot of photos of it. It looks so beautiful, although when I was there one of the panels of the bridge was covered with plexiglass so no locks could be put on it. As beautiful as the display looks, and as nice as the idea is, the locks have been causing a lot of damage to the bridges and some have even collapsed from the weight of the metal, so it's hard to say how long the city will keep them up, even as iconic as they are. My advice would be to see Paris before anything is decided about taking them down because they really are beautiful. I also advise you to come prepared with a lock because there are a lot of people selling them on the street and they're extremely overpriced (just like pretty much anything people selling on the street there offer). One more thing, if you're on this bridge, look for this giant antique looking lock, it's sitting at the top of the railing and stands out easily. It was by far my favourite.

What a charming hotel! The staff was so welcoming. We really enjoyed our time in the champagne lounge - great service, memorable conversation, and delicious champagne recommendations. Our room was perfectly appointed. The only odd thing was the toilet that was jammed in so tightly next to a window with a shower curtain that it felt a little awkward to use. But a minor quible considering the historic rooms! We can't wait to return!

We spent five nights in a row at "the oldest Champagne Bar in Paris" under the fine service of Remi, who definitely knows his grapes! This is not a "people watching cafe" but rather a step back into another time with candle light (yes real candles!) and an assortment of the finest Champagnes. Tables are perfect for two. There are two seating areas - one near the bar and the other with a fireplace.  I would say's it is not good for groups but you could get a decent sized group in here, but I wouldn't get too loud. The vibe is definitely chill while you sip champagne.Again I can't say enough about Remi, who was everything and everywhere. He is definitely service-oriented and quite friendly. His two years living in the UK helps with his English as well.

Very nice property. We have the Eiffel suite #608 and it was amazing!!! Best view I have ever had in Paris. The staff was amazing with the exception of one gentlemen that worked the champagne lounge on Tuesday March 10, 2020. He was rude to my wife and I and certainly did not appreciate it business.

Great boutique hotel near all the attractions. Small and intimate with old world charm.  Spent 4 nights here and enjoyed every minute.  Rooms are tiny but well appointed and clean.  Special thanks to Angelo, Marie,and Remi who treated us like royalty.  Highly recommend this hotel.

Gorgeous champagne lounge and wonderful staff. Very informative and totally not pretentious. We had the tasting of 3 champagnes and learned all about the differences between cru, grande cru, brut, extra brut, blanc de noirs, etc etc. Lovely presentation.

The room is a major disappointment. Spent 30,000 Starwood points for a category 6 hotel and the room is the size of a shoebox. What makes matters worse is that we told the hotel ahead of time we were traveling with a number of people and they assured us the room we were assigned is much larger than reality. Called downstairs at 2pm to ask the concierge a question and was told the concierge isn't here for another hour or two.Hotel lobby is equally small and unimpressive.

The restaurant is in the ground floor of the Radisson Blu of the same name.The full breakfast (30 euros as of 07/2015) has a selection of items that are prepared at your request.Fine cheese platter (very high quality), various hams, various croissants on a platter, fruit smoothies (I had the mango which was fantastic), plain and fruit yogurts, various freshly squeezed fruit juices, made to order omelettes, coffee, etc. The restaurant is very private and quiet. Dress attire at breakfast is casual. Overall this was the best breakfast I had in Paris and I highly recommend this restaurant.
We came just for the bar.  Apparently one of the first champagne bars (if not the first) in Paris?  Excellent decor, excellent service, and a really great champagne tasting.

My husband and I had a wonderful experience here tonight!! The ambiance and vibe were so lovely. Our waiter was extremely knowledgable and kind. The champagne was excellent as well. We ordered the sampler so we could try the different kinds of champagne. We will be coming back before we leave Paris!

Super champagne tasting experienceWe booked room at the hotel and on our first night we joined the champagne tasting event. A special event they have every month. The well known sommelier explained us all special facts about the champagnes. We had a wonderful evening with lovely champagnes.

name: France Tourisme
address: 6 rue de l'Amiral de Coligny 75001 Paris France

reviews.review: We arrived 15 minutes early on 10-14-2024 at the France Tourisme office as requested, and were told to wait outside until the tour guide showed up at 9:00 am.  Our guide met us around 9:15 am and we arrived at the Louvre around 9:30 am.  Unfortunately, the Louvre did not open that day until 10:45 am.  While this was not our guide's fault, the tour was rushed.  The tour guide had another tour scheduled after ours, and felt obligated to tend to their needs instead of ours.  This indicates that France Tourisme does not allow adequate time between tours to address unexpected scheduling challenges.  The guide offered to meet us later, but of course we all had other plans that we couldn't change.  She dumped us in the Mona Lisa room behind a large crowd of other visitors.  Given how bad this tour was, we should have all been given refunds for this very poor experience.  In addition, other tours I have been on offered the opportunity to rate the service.  France Tourisme did not, and I suspect this is because they know how bad the tour was.  I am therefore posting this review on Yelp.  I recommend that you skip this tour, and attend the Louvre on your own.  You'll have a better experience.

I have booked 6 tours with them, two of tours were cancelled. My 1st tour was Loire valley castles tour, they cancelled my tour after 4 pm the day before the tour started.  Due to our travelling , we did not have a chance to check email, we got up 6 am to wait at the meeting place for 7: 15 tour, later we realized the car did not come, then found out tour cancelled.  I booked the tour 2 months in advance, never thought of the possibility of being cancelled.  I ended up booking  Loire valley castles tour with getyourguide . France Tourisme is a small group of 8 people, price was better than getyourguide. The guide was professional, if you manage to join to tour, it is great, but also you need to be flexible to be cancelled at the last mins, I mean less than 24 hour notice, which can risk ruining your holiday.  Luckily I managed to cancel one of my tour and did the pre booked museum 2 days in advance to rebook my Loire tour with another company.

9:30PM Night Tour of Paris...Paris is a visual city. One of the best ways to orient yourself is with the popular two-hour tourist bus tours that loop the city center. After searching through AD's for objective reviews: (https://freetoursbyfoot.com/hop-on-hop-off-paris/), we saved a few euros by scheduling a night tour, a day before on their website. Navigating activities, times, connections, streets, maps, names, transport and stops takes real dedication. So, why not leave the driving to a tour company?Since we were arriving in the afternoon, it was expected that we would encounter rush hour. Too late for a daylight tour or even the 7:00PM night tour, although that's what we would have preferred since its right around sunset and warmer.Meeting near Rivoli Metro station we verified that we were paid passengers at the front desk. The bus was on time and once folks got their earplugs, there was a mad unorganized scramble to board the bus for folks to reach the open air upper deck.We started off in the loop from Notre Dame (unlit), Seine to Left Bank to Eiffel Tower, rounding the Champs Eylsees to the Arc de Triomphe, the Opera House, Moulin Rouge and back. Sitting towards the middle of the bus gives the best all around views. Best photographs are when the bus stops completely. Bring a jacket and scarf. Lots of those folks who rushed the top deck eventually went below since it gets cool as the evening wears on.For 20È its a quick cheap way to orient yourself and snap a few great pics. Audio was okay if you're paying attention.  PS to past reviewers- it's one of the cheapest tour companies in Paris. So you kind of get what you pay for...
The people here are friendly not overly welcoming but they are good. And there are a lot of Great excursions.Sara our tour guide host on the bus was good.

I had a great time going to Normandy with them. They speak English and our guide Jeremy went above and beyond. However I wouldn't book the lunch and go eat at any restaurant on your own as the choices are ok. It doesn't cost much more for something you'll enjoy a lot more! They're are very user friendly for new adventures aka first time travelers.

They drive by too fast across monuments and architectural building  for you to take a look at them at night. The bus has high windows which ruins the view for most of the  architecture. They have different price on the website than at the store and won't price match even if you show them.  The only good part is if you are short on time you will get a chance to  see all the famous structures night view  in 1 hour but to me it was waste of 22 euros
Did the Dinner Cruise Lounge on the club chair lounge boat - best deal in Paris.Boat was clean - food very good / service excellent and you can't beat the price. Even accommodated vegetarians.

i stumbled into this place looking for the Paris Tourist place and was glad I did.  I wanted to take a trip to Versailles and although I am a confident metro and train user, I was pretty sure there would be a long walk from the Versaille train station to the Versailles Palace.So for about 50€, I joined them at their Louvre location and left for a half day visit.  On their end, everything was as promised.  A ride and a bit of an introduction and some sight-seeing tips on our way home.  The only disappointment was paying an extra 10€ to see a water show in the Versailles garden which didn't seem to exist, but everyone was paying the extra tariff, not just customers of Tourisme.  My dealings with them were accurate and knowledgeable and fair -- just what is needed in a tour provider.  Their meeting place had a downstairs loo and snacks for sale.
We were not happy with the fact they forgot to account for our infant in the booking.

The only reason I give this company 2 stars is because our guide, Nicholas was FANTASTIC. If not for him, I would give this company 0 stars. We did a day trip to Mont St Michel on Monday, April 22nd, 2019. We paid for pick up and drop off service from/to our hotel. Pick up service was fine and our tour was fine. The problem came with the return. Apparently this company doesn't take traffic into account when you are returning from an excursion that is 4 hours from Paris. We encountered quite a bit of traffic on the return back, so instead of getting back at 9pm our bus didn't get back until 10pm. Before we even arrived back, our tour guide, Nicholas, came to me and said that because of traffic and the bus being delayed, our ride back to our hotel was being cancelled. I'm sorry, but WHAT??!! Mind you I am a single female with my 17 year old daughter, and this was first trip overseas. We knew NOTHING about the taxis or the metro system and UBER was saying it would be a wait of 30 minutes. Anger was coming off of me in massive waves. How do you not account for TRAFFIC?!! This was horrible. When we finally get back, of course the company is closed and there is no way to get help from anyone. TERRIBLE SERVICE. Here is where the 2 stars I did give this place come in. Our guide, Nicholas, saw how upset I was and asked where we were staying. He took time from going home himself to get us back to our hotel. He didn't have a car, but he took us on the metro. Stayed with us on the train, and then walked us to our hotel. That man is what customer service is all about. I can't say the same for the rest of this company. It took a beautiful day and made it a horrible experience. I did get refunded for the return trip, but trust me when I say, customer safety and satisfaction is not a priority at all for this company. If you book through them, do not use the pickup/drop off hotel option because the slightest delay will cause them to cancel it....even TRAFFIC DELAYS. This company needs to incorporate a practice of staying open until all of their buses are back in case of issues like this. Closing, and leaving people stranded is a horrible way to do business.

I really enjoyed the tour in Saint-Germain-des-Près with Lisa as she's got a great sense of humor to spice up our tour. We got to taste many different things from "financier" to "merveilleux" which I've never heard of before in the US. And the cheese tasting paired with the wine was delectable. I would recommend this tour to any foodies who wants to explore some local areas.

The best tour you can get in Paris. I felt like a local! We went to places I didn't expect to go as a tourist. Lisa did an amazing job answering all of our questions, giving us the history of everywhere we went/everything we ate, and gave us some tips to help us while we're in Paris! We started at a cafe and tasted some yummy croissants with coffee and juice. We got to try some authentic jams. We stopped for some desserts and baguettes. We got to explore a local market. We sat down and ate some French cheeses with wines that paired well with them. Definitely an experience that I will remember and recommend!

Lisa is one of a kind. This tour goes far beyond many I have taken in the past. Lisa is a warm, intelligent tour guide who takes you to vendors who are masters at their trade. From sweets to savory, everything is beyond perfect!!! I felt I got a whole taste of Paris in a few short hours.

Highly recommend this food tour to those wanting a unique experience in Paris! Had a nice variety of tastings ranging from pastries to pâté. The guide, Lisa, did a lovely job showing us around. She gave us a lot of history about the area, shops, and food and was extremely personable and enthusiastic about the tour.

We had a wonderful afternoon with Lisa on the Original Flavors of Paris walking tour! She gave us some great history and information about the Saint-Germain-des-Prés neighborhood and guided us to some delicious local spots. We started at a cafe for croissants and espresso. We made a few stops for baguettes and desserts. We then stopped at an adorable store where we tasted some olive oils and did a little shopping. We finished up at a very chic local market, where we sat down and had a selection of cheeses and wine, along with our baguette and delicious desserts! It was a delightfully Parisian way to spend our afternoon. She also offered us some really great suggestions for other stores and restaurants to visit during our stay in Paris! Overall, we highly recommend booking one of her tours!

such a great tour. I didn't really know what to expect going into it but I had such a great time. I got to try new flavors and learn about the history of the food and place. I recommend this tour to everyone wanting to experience new things!

I was visiting Paris and decided to attend the Flavors of Paris food tour through the Marais and I had the most amazing time. I have visited Paris in the past and done other food tours but Lisa's tour was unlike no other! We were able to taste Parisian pastries and authentic spreads while Lisa took us around the beautiful Marais district. I really felt like a local and learned so much about the city that I never would've known. I will definitely be recommending Flavors of Paris to friends and family. Thanks again Lisa!

I had just been in Paris for a little over three weeks when I decided to do the Flavors of Paris tour. It was the first time I was on a food tour of any sort, but I wanted to get to know some neighborhoods better and gain an appreciation for the sweets and pastries that I was consuming on a semi-regular basis. This tour did just that! Lisa, the tour guide was a delight and gave us a peek into the life of Parisians, current and past, through the anecdotes she told as we walked through historic side streets and stories of the local vendors that she had befriended. The tour allowed me to see the neighborhood of Saint-Germain in a new way and of course, the food was delicious!

I have lived in Paris over 6 years, and I wanted to know more about Le Marais. Lisa was recommended to me by a friend. She was an outstanding guide. Very personable and she really knows her subject. She pointed out things about the Marais that most people who have lived there don't know. I highly recommend her.

I've lived in Paris for almost 3 years now and I feel like I know the scene pretty well, but thanks to the generosity of a friend I recently had the chance to take a tour with Flavors of Paris.  Best advice I can give?  Don't eat for 24 hours beforehand and be ready for a culinary tour de force!  Lisa's tour will take you to some out of the way places you might not otherwise have discovered, and you'll hear from passionate professionals about their handcrafted eatables!

Although I am not into antiques, this is a really cool place. They had so many nice things in this area, including yarn and fabric things there was one special shop that had a lot of vintage things that I thought were really cool. If I had brought my suitcase I would buy something.

One of my favourite Parisian indoor gallery with a beautiful range of stores (decoration, optician, flower shop, soap shop, fabrics...) I make a point of  visiting this Passage to remind me how much I love Paris. This is one of the most secret location, that still holds the Parisianisme style that belongs to another era.

name: Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie

reviews.review: We try to check out the science museums in each city we visit (if it doesn't seem to kiddy-ish) because my husband is a big kid at heart. We arrived on a Wednesday a little before 1:30. This is when all the school kids were arriving. Luckily, we didn't really run into them because they weren't really at the exhibits. I guess they may have separate activity rooms for school trips. This science museum was pretty fun. I learned a few things and there were a good amount of interactive exhibits, including one social experiment, which I won't spoil for you. We spent about two hours there and pretty much explored the whole museum.Tip - the museum is a part of the Museum Pass. It's not quite in the city centre but only takes a quick 20-30 minute metro ride.

Wow this is the best science museum that I've ever been too. By far (especially compared to my local place... Liberty Science center in NJ). Most science centers are essentially glorified playgrounds/ learning centers for kids. This place actually was more targeted towards adults and teens. In fact during the weekday that we visited, it was almost exclusively adults. The exhibits are extremely interesting and informative and I learned a lot. I could've spent at least an entire day here (in contrast to the art museums like the Louvre where I was bored out of my mind). The different sections are in good working order. Many exhibits are in both English and French (although there are some that are French only). There was a really cool interactive sports exhibit too when we visited too. We got the explorer ticket that gets you access to the Planetarium as well as the special exhibits in addition to regular admission. I'd say that this is worth it as the Planetarium was awesome. Huge screen, comfortable seats, very interesting documentaries. Free WiFi. Very close to metro station. Will return on my next trip to Paris.
This is probably a better place for small childrenwho can interact with science. They have a planetarium, a few airplanes.

liked it a lot.  I will add that they are strict about starting and ending times, and security is tight.  I would say it is bigger than COSI in Columbus, Ohio.  very interactive learning with my 4 year old. she had a blast.

Lame. We are ppl that crawl science museums. Most of the displays are on a screen. I could just do that at home with my iPad.... The remaining interactive display of seeing inertia in the math section, refused entry for us because we did not speak french. They should have stated that before we purchase our ticketAlso, the kids or enfant area is closed at 3:15 while the rest of the museum closes at six. No where in the museum displays that info. Nor were we told. This is very lame. Perhaps we just came back from the German museum in Munich and the cosmo caixa in Barcelona, and being a regular attender is all science museums in most of western United States. Save your time. Go do something else with your kids. Taking a course on coursera is better than this

This is one of the most tactile museums I've ever been to. It's enormous, with several sections devoted to different branches of science: biology, botany, mathmatics, physics, etc. But the content is not etherally abrstract; it's what is applicable to the ordinary person - the car you drive in, the food you eat, the innovative design of your home stereo system, etc. And as much as possible, the exhibits engage your sense of touch and hearing as well as sight. In addition to the numerous exhibits, there is a steady stream of seminars (various topics) held throughout the day in different locations. Anyone can join the audience. The exhibits are quite accessible to tourists as well as the French, with most descriptions, explanations, and museum signs in English as well as Spanish. I was also impressed by consistent use of Braille signs and even some visual exhibits translated into a bas-relief pannel. There is also a planetarium with five or so shows. The planetarium itself is quite comfortable and the projection was good, though I found the presentation about the solar system a little disappointing - lacking in interesting content. There is, however, the Geode movie theatre for more modern scientific films. There is also a submarine on the site, the Argonaute, open for touring. This is located in the lovely gardens behind the centre. On the lower floor, you'll find a small but nice aquarium next to one of the restaurants. The Cité houses a large library stocked with science books, DVD/CDs and magazines/journals of all kinds. There are confortable tables and chairs for study, (and these are used quite regularly by local students and professionals). There's a kid's section to the library (as well as one in the museum proper). The ticket price for one day is somewhat pricey, but for only four Euros more, you can have access for one full year. It's a good deal (for a local) as you can't do justice to all the exhibits in one day. The library is free, but you need to pay a reasonable annual fee borrow items. The Geode movies are extra, about 10 Euros a ticket. The only reason I wouldn't give the Cité five stars is that, as big and impressive as it is, it's showing signs of wear and lack of maintenance. In one section I visited, about a third of the interactive displays were not working. In another section, several video screens were blank. There are tons of security guards on site, but maybe not enough curators?...hmmm.

The munchkins and I took a day for yourselves and decided to visit the Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie during our recent trip to Paris.I've been to a lot of science museums over the years including Los Angeles, Chicago, Portland, and San Francisco and I have to say that this is one of the best science museums I've ever visited.For the tourists, the vast majority of exhibits had copy in English so we were able to enjoy the museum despite not being fluent in French.The museum itself was very reasonably priced.  We went ahead and got tickets to two of the extra exhibits which were actually more than the normal price of admission.The exhibits were engaging for the munchkins and interesting for myself (an engineer).  One thing that I really noticed (and enjoyed) was that so many of the exhibits weren't just about science, but had an artistic angle.  The robotics traveling exhibit was more about the art and aesthetics of robots than the actual technology.They also had the standard fare of Earth sciences, astronomy, sound, light, etc.  All done in a very interesting and hand-on manner to engage the munchkins.This was an enjoyable and unique way to spend of our days in Paris.  I would suggest that for a family traveling to Paris with kids it would be a fantastic diversion at the 1/2 way point of a vacation.As a final aside, the second traveling exhibit was about the history of video games, which made me feel nostalgic and old.

This is a nice museum to take kids - the -1 floor (one floor down from the ground floor) has a nice but incredibly  busy section designed to engage kids in testing all sorts of scientific experiments. It costs 11 euros per person (les for kids I think), so go for a full day. And eat well before - there is a McDonald's across from the front entrance and the food there is much more reasonably priced than anything in the museum. I liked the adult exhibits (we dropped our friends with children off on the ground floor and then had a quiet look around upstairs). The exhibit on the future of fashion was great and there was a section on existing but futuristic products that we liked a lot (though it is a bit like a high-priced shopping exhibit). Our favourite bit was the future of urban society where they showed the different living standards of modern cities and how architects and construction experts are planning to build more eco-friendly homes. Next time I'd like to see one of their 3D surround-sound films in the Epcot-centre-like theater in the back.

Just wanted to do something for my 10 and 12 year old. This was great. We spent 5 hours wondering around the museum. The submarine outside had 1 hour wait kids gave up after 20 minutes. Planetarium movie was great, the seats are so nice I almost fell asleep sitting in them. You can get a translating device. Make sure you have an ID they will keep until you return them back. The translating devices out of three they gave us only one worked which I gave to the kids to share during the movie. This was kind of disappointing. My 10 year old did not let go of the device so my 12 year old was unable to hear the complete movie. I did tell them their devices did not work, the lady at the counter was not so concerned. It looked like some Japanese tourists had the same issue.However, it was a place where I let my kids decide what they want to do and see, I walked after them. They needed this after all other museums they walked after me and listened to me patiently.
It's good place for young people. Science become easier here.

Great place to have a frozen margarita after watching Olympic boxing.  This could be my 'resting place' after a day of running around around trying to soak up the Olympic Spirit.  It isn't quite California level of Mexican ( except for the tequila and cocktails) but is is so satisfying to get this close so far away from home!

Just no! Sorry. This wouldn't work at all in the states as this is so not Mexican food. We walked a lot this particular day and we wanted to have some comfort food so here we go. To start we ordered and Iced coffee and that was the first mistake from a list of quite a few. It was so not iced coffee in the least, and if you serve Iced coffee in any Mexican restaurant it should have the taste of cinnamon. But that's neither here nor there as this wasn't the brunt of what the experience was. Ordered a quesadilla. And oh boy here we go. The was not what I would ever call a quesadilla in the least. This was not Mexican at all so maybe this should be revisited when it comes to authenticity. Okay here goes, the spinach salad next, it was NOT spinach. Looked more like Kale and that is not typical at all. It also had some kind of meat but I can't describe it.  I don't know maybe it was me but this isn't a Mexican restaurant in my eyes. The waitress was awesome and the place is cute, but Mexian food? No not at all and I wouldn't recommend this spot. Plus no one e spoke spanish! Skip this one! Couldn't finish my food as I was so in the mood for Mexican!

Decent drinks. Highly recommend the maragritas and Caprihina. The drinks are fresh and pretty close to authentic (coming from a Texan). We had the nachos which were okay. They came with a lot of toppings.

Great location with awesome Mexican food. I was surprised how good it was!They have margaritas like no other place I've tried here in Paris. There's happy hour so that's a huge win win.I got the Mexican burger it was good just wasn't a fan of the potato that was served with it.Salsa and Tostitos that come before your meal are better then the ones you buy at the grocery store. Super salty and delicious.

Mexican food in Paris? Sí! We stopped in on a whim to escape some crowds, use the free wifi, and grab a bite. As a wine drinker, I was impressed by the wine list here. We ordered a Côtes de Provence Rosè. Yum. The food: it's a-ok. Not amazing, but certainly not leaving-you-hungry-because-you-didn't-eat-it quality. We both had the huevos rancheros. Interesting with bacon. Not so great with over-hard eggs. Order with eggs over easy and you're good to go! Add some of the spicy salsa they bring with the chips and voila: deliscioisness. We finished up with cafe creama. Good. Would recommend.

Dinner - October 12, 2019. The resto was busy but not full. Service was a bit slow, and wait staff not too attentive or friendly. It took forever to get a menu and to place our order. Ordered taco carnitas. The carnitas seasoning was delicious, but they gave plain white rice that's somewhat dry and boiled black beans that's so bland. Also ordered mole chicken enchilada. I expected the mole generously covering the two enchiladas; instead, what I got was probably half a spoonful of mole smeared on the enchiladas. What a shame. The mole was like an afterthought and also not good. Again, dry plain white rice, bland beans. Chips was fresh and crunchy and came with delicious salsa. Regular margarita was bad, cinnamon margarita was good.Location was perfect. As a resident of Northern California, my standard for Mexican food is set so high.

I think this place is notorious for its pitchers of margarita during happy hour. It's half price until 8pm (so around 25€ for a liter), but it's a good value and above all, it's STRONG. Don't make the rookie mistake of splitting a liter of it between 2 people unless you're looking to get tipsy ;) That being said, happy hour ends quite early (8) and prices quickly jump after that (50+ euros for a pitcher is kinda steep...)Obviously, the other half of the reason why you come here is for the Mexican food. Unfortunately, it is at best underwhelming. I guess the delicious margarita set the bar kinda high for me, but I was disappointed in my food. It wasn't terrible, but it was just nothing special. This place seems to be really popular, and in nice weather, the outdoor seating fills up quickly.If you come here, get here before 8 so you can take advantage of the happy hour!

Being American and having some of the best Mexican food in my home area it was a bit of a stretch eating Mexican food in Paris. But we had walked a lot for our first day and we were hungry and tired. This bar/restaurant was the only spot in our new neighborhood we could find still open so we ordered chips with spicy salsa and guacamole as well as nachos with cheese and jalapeños. We sat on the sidewalk, theatre style. Our entertainment for the evening was watching people park the tiniest cars into the tiniest parking spots. Impressive talent!

I am from Texas so I have pretty high standards of anyone claiming to have Mexican food. I am here for four months so I thought I would try it to get a taste of home. The salsa was actually spicy so me and my friend got a little excited that the food would we good. The plate of the day came out and what we heard was not what we got. It tasted a lot more like curry than anything else. The dessert was good but really small :( The cafe that accompanied was so strong but I am in Paris. The service was meh

1.5 starsI'm sorry, what is this whitish-green stuff? Guacamole? No, no. I'm sure you're mistaken. No? Okay then... What should I use to eat the "guacamole" with? Chips, right? Oh, I have to pay for them? Um, okay... And you referred to this thing on my plate as what? An enchilada? But enchiladas are supposed to have red or green sauce. This is sort of a strange yellow-gold-white color. Are you just kidding with me or are you serious? And this margarita I ordered - isn't it supposed to look at least somewhat like the one in the picture on the table proclaiming "8€ margaritas!"? It's half the size the of the one in the photo. I guess the photo is just there for dramatic effect? (Insert sad face and image of me not having fun anymore.)And then there was the service. Okay, so normally I complain up and down about the rude waiters in Paris. This restaurant is the only one in the city where you'll be inundated with waiters who are frighteningly attentive.  And in their snazzy tight-fitting t-shirts, none the less. It's like I went through a time warp to happy hour at an Applebee's back home. Oy. But by attentive, I mean that they don't communicate with one another. Every two minutes or so a different one will end up at your table and ask you the same question that the other three servers before them asked you.In a nutshell, don't go here. If you're American here on vacation, you can wait the few days it will take you to get back home to get your Mexican fix. If you're an American living in Paris, get your fix at Rice and Beans or El Nopal or Candelaria. And if you're French looking to try Mexican food, save your money and buy a ticket to Mexico or California.
Good Food and service. Very nice setting and friendly staff.  We had an awesome and relaxing meal !
Wait staff were super attentive and everything treated great. The rump steak was a little tough. Duck was delicious.Waiter even took time to translate and explain menu to us.

The confit de canard was AMAZING!  The rest of the food we ordered were good as well but eating this dish in particular was an unforgettable experience.  It's been 7 months since my family and I ate at this restaurant and I still talk about it.  I've been recommending this place to family and friends who plan to visit Paris. The price is very affordable. The place is small yet cozy. The staff is friendly. Try it!!!

The serving staff is friendly, attentive and patient. We came in as a group of 4 Americans and up until eating here didn't see much hospitality in Paris. The server took his time to explain the menu in English and was extremely friendly! I ordered a steak and it came with green beans and potatoes. Everything had great flavor and the butter on top of the steak was one of the best steak butters we've ever had. My friends and I were arguing over what kind of butter it was, so if anyone knows... let me know! Prices were reasonable. Sorry I don't remember exactly how much it cost. And they have a good beer selection. There's also happy hour shots for only 5 euros!
Very nicely decorated place, located in a great neighborhood and easily found. Great food, tapas and drinks. And friendly staff. I will definitely return.

We found Le Smoke during our recent visit to Paris, France. We were in search of a reasonably priced restaurant that would also present as a tasty/not overpriced meal, which had proven itself difficult in this city. Upon arrival the staff was very attentive and our waiter took the time to explain every detail of the menu to us in English. He was absolutely fabulous and the service was on point. We both decided to go with two of the plate of the days: Chicken with a mushroom sauce accompanied with pasta and the Duck with Green Beans and Roasted Potatoes.  Both dishes were very reasonable for the price but were very simple. The meals were also served with the classic hot mustard on the side.

Best place to taste real Parisian food with just the right price, waiters are very friendly and we're kind enough to translate the very French menu into English Nice cozy place not very quiet though, we're very satisfied with everything & we're sure to come here again whenever in Paris #Recommended

I really liked this place. I was looking for a chill place to grab a beer and a bite to eat on Friday and this place delivered. Beers were pretty inexpensive. The bartender was extremely helpful in explaining the menu. I went with the quiche. It came out and was perfectly moist, with crispy potatoes and a side salad that wasn't slathered in dressing all for 8.50 euro. The bar also had a unique vibe compared to a lot of the other Paris bars that I went to. It was a little small but was worth hitting up for a quick bite if you are in the area.
Great local find. Refreshingly reasonable prices. Good beer. Chicken was good but not out of this world, steak was tough at med- rare

This is a nice tucked away little gem that is English friendly but popular with French foodies as well. Dark and atmospheric with jazz dec, part restaurant and part bar with a super chill vibe and more affordable prices than most of the restaurants in the area. We had the duck breast with pepper sauce (seared rare & absolutely amazing) and the cheeseburger (very good as well), portions are generous and the bread served with dinner was delicious as well. I would love to come back and try their desserts.

Le Petit Palais a free art museum near a lot of notable Parisian locations.  With art spanning from the renaissance to present, they even have a Monet.  If you're looking to kill an hour sometime during your stay, I'd highly recommend stopping by.

A free museum is not something I thought I'd come across in Paris, but Petit Palais is just that! Aside from its beautiful exterior, Petit Palais also boasts a broad collection of art from sculptures and paintings, to royal relics once housed by the royals. There is also a beautiful outside courtyard lined with chairs to relax and take in the beauty. While this museum isn't huge, it's a great way to spend a little bit of your time while in Paris. Of course if you're really into art you could spend hours where, but since it's free it's easy to stop in for a short amount of time and get your art fix. We went on a weekday afternoon and got in immediately, no line, just a quick bag check.

We toured Paris with a local on May 1, on which every museum is closed. Our pal wanted to show us this place, one of her favourite spots in Paris, but expected it to be be closed too. But it was open! And the permanent collection is free.The cafe is lovely, there's a large indoor space, plus several tables outside in the garden. Get a table here and enjoy feeling like a Parisian aristocrat for a few minutes as you sip your coffee, eat your cake, then take a look at the beautiful paintings in the main collection. It's a smaller museum, so you can take in some art without feeling overwhelmed. There are some lovely works here and I highly recommend this spot if you're wandering the historic sights, need a coffee break, and want to be inside a beautiful palace without dropping any Euros.

If you ever arrive in Paris and forget or fail to get a reservation at the Musee d'Orsay or Louvre-- check this place out! It's not only beautiful, extensive, less crowded-- but free! There's something for all art lovers and you can also buy tickets for special exhibitions. We saw an incredible, comprehensive early 20th century show on Paris art and culture with Picasso, Cocteau, Man Ray, dance, fashion, etc.

Walking back to our hotel we passed the ornate palace.  It is on the corner of Winston Churchill Blvd & the Champs-Elysees; Winston stands guard at the corner.The doors were opened, there was no charge so wandered inside.  There were frescos on the ceiling, tiled walkways, a lush garden, statues, a lot of beautiful art & a large gift shop.The Petit Palace was built for the 1900 Universal Exhibition & is now the now the City of Paris Museum of Fine Arts.  It is across opposite the Grand Palais that appeared boarded up.

Do you want to stand in a long line to get tickets? Do you want to shuffle through the stuffy crowded rooms? Do you want to NOT be able to see famous art because it is mobbed by hordes of camera armed tourists?Then this museum is not for you (Louvre is though)However, if you want a free admission to a beautiful airy and spacious museum that houses variety of art (including famous one like Rembrandt), then Petit Palais is a great choice. You will not regret it.

Free entry and wonderful! The building is stunning and not too large so quite easy to quickly cruise through in under an hour or spend all afternoon here. You can relax in the garden in lounge chairs  and get food from the cafe and read about the art with the free Wi-Fi. Underrate museum in Paris but very charming and worth a visiting!

This is a great art museum, a well organized and manageably sized collection across styles ranging from Orthodox icons to Dutch masters to Impressionists. All presented in a great building with a relaxing garden courtyard. Oh, and it's free. But despite all of this, it's easy to move around and take your time.

What a gorgeous building!  I went here yesterday with a tour group & the outside/inside is beautiful.  Be sure to look up; there are so many details in the ceiling & walls that you will miss if you don't have a proper look & take it all in.  The main exhibit halls are free.

What a beautiful sight to see - and it's FREE! If you want to take a break from the hustle and bustle of the retail filled Champs-Élysées, this is your spot.Although it's name is the Petit Palais, it surely is large and grand. Located across from the larger, Grand Palaias, and was built for the World Fair in 1900. It's an absolutely beautiful structure that houses an impressive art collection.It also has a lovely garden, with plenty of seating. It's adjacent to a small cafe where you can pick up a snack. We were very tired from walking at this point, so we grabbed a glass of wine, and sat down to take in the beauty of the garden during golden hour - aka sunset time.I would definitely make a stop here if you're in the area - beautiful interior and again FREE!

Absolutely stunning theater in the center of Paris. This is the kind of theater that is in the movies. It is very classic and Baroque in setting and is it's fun for the intermission as it is for the show!At intermission grab a glass of champagne and head out to the beautiful glass walls to see a view of the hotel de ville or Notre Dame Cathedral and tour St Jaques.Pretend you're in dangerous liaisons as you slip in and out of the multi-tiered theater with arched balcony areas

Broadway came to Paris with "Bob Fosse, the Show" at the Théâtre du Châtelet (built 1862), showcasing stage work of the dance icon-choreographer with a cast led by Ben Vereen. showstoppers Bye-bye, Mein Herr from 'Cabaret'; Mr. Bojangles from 'Dancin'; and Sweet Charity, Big Spender from 'Chicago' wowed the capacity audience of kids, parents, uni students to grandparents. much the same mix of theatergoers in NY. except in Paris, the crowd seemed mainly local(broadway mostly tourists).

A very old looking theater that has seen a lot of history. Last year we listened to a performance of strings by local artists that was very good. It was a great place to hear music because it was like a 18th century drawing room. Only thing missing were white wigs and powdered faces.
a beautiful park -- great to walk around with an amazing science museum and the best part -- during the summer wonderful out door movies!

This is probably the most iconic spot in Paris and whether it's day or night, it's absolutely stunning. Getting right up close requires an entrance fee, but the structure is massive and can easily be seen from multiple areas nearby (alongside throughout the city). We found the grounds below made for a perfect spot to sit and eat lunch on one of the benches. There's a metro stop nearby, which was awesome for having access via public transportation. It's an awesome photo opp spot. Definitely recommend checking it out!

Eiffel Tower Romance Sometimes I need to take a imaginary trip in time. That's this review. It happened in reality a long time ago. I'm getting away now by going back to visit in my fantasies. When you go to Paris you must see the tourist attractions. The day my daughter planned to visit the neighborhood of the Eiffel Tower turned out to be very windy. That was my last visit to Paris. We went, saw, I took my photos, and then we sat in a nearby cafe for a warm cup of Espresso. The travel price is very good in the Fall. Now with Covid it doesn't look like anyone will be Romantic here! Unless you are a resident maybe. One visit I was there in August. That was definitely before Global Warming. My daughter and I went to Paris in the Fall. It was a beautiful cool week. I would visit Paris again in a warmer month to go up in the Eiffel Tower again. I would love to see the city once more from the Eiffel Tower. The important thing is to consider the weather before you go. I did purchase a tiny replica souvenir from a Street Vendor. The deals on souvenirs are much better from a vendor than at the Tower. I have my little Eiffel Tower where I see it every day. In my opinion this landmark is the Romantic equal to meeting on the Observation Deck of the Empire State Building. Meeting someone at the Eiffel Tower (or Honeymooners visiting) is very Romantic to me. I just happened to be there with friends or my daughter when I visited. Fun but I wouldn't say romantic! I used my imagination.

It looks amazing from any angle you look at it from, you do not have to pay to enjoy this beautiful monument. I personally walked by Rue de l'Université and took fantastic photos from there, walked by the park (grass area) underneath the Eiffel tower and also took great pictures there, to look at it from a view I paid the Arc de Triomphe at night and looked at it lid up and it was the most beautiful view you can imagine. I did not see any bad people around the area, just sellers but nobody bothered me or tried to steal anything, my experience was great!

For an anniversary, I had reserved an Airbnb with the view of the Eiffel and the bridge. Little did I know, it would be so close to the Eiffel, we just needed to walk down the stairs and voila! It was such an amazing surprise! I kid you not, we were there EVERY SINGLE DAY! Who is to say that's not the dream? It sure was mine and it was brought to life! The busy bustling streets, the crowded transit and the street performances gave me chills! The daily baked fresh bread and the choices of the pastry was enormous! I can't lie, if I said we gained so much weight in Paris because of all the food places close by! Just a result of us being so close, but definitely a plus! A highlight of my trip!I'll be back for you, mon amor!

Always saw this as one of the world's most amazing architectural structures. The closer I got, the more in awe I was. Stood in line for over two hours to get an elevator ticket to the top! So worth it, the view was breathtaking.
Annual Christmas Vacation 2022 for The Lee-Lole's. Started our trip in London and made our way to check out Paris!

It's an iconic place and you get so the vibes it's beautiful at night I'm eating it 5 stars simply because it's true to its rep it's like what the Statue of Liberty wanted to be but didn't achieve. This place is often replicated but not duplicated; therefore if you find yourself in the areas just go cmon it's a memory of a lifetime.
The Eiffel tower such a beautiful site. For a fee you can take the elevator to the top and enjoy a breath taking view of the city

I honestly never knew how absolutely stunning this was. I do not think anyone is fully prepared for how amazing this thing is until you actually go see it for yourself. We went several times during the day and you can see it from just about anywhere, but to stand beside it and look up at it with all its glory... Damn Paris, I'm in love.On our last night, after a very special dinner, we hopped on scooters and scooted on over. we arrived just before midnight and found the perfect viewing spot. When the clock stricked 12.... the tower started to sparkle and WOW, just talking about it now is taking my breath away. For a full 5 min, we just stared at it, in complete awe. (The tower sparkles for the first 5 min of every hour - just be sure to check what hour it begins at, but my reccomendation is to go at midnight, its so damn special.)Paris, I love you!

If you are visiting Paris. You can't  leave Paris with out a visit to the Eiffel Tower.  I recommend you wear comfortable shoes and be prepared for lines.  It's well worth the wait to see the Eiffel Tower. I absolutely loved the spectacular views of Paris.  You won't be disappointed!  Definitely check out the amazing brassiere's in the area. You can sit down and enjoy seeing the Eiffel Tower.   I personally feel it's a must visit when in Paris!  I definitely was not disappointed and would visit again in the near future.
Fantastic service and brilliant crepes RRUSH  over to this great little crepe place definitely worth the journey and very reasonable prices  excellent value

We came here first thing in the morning before going around Paris. There was a line but the owner worked quickly. The crepes were delicious and the owner was so friendly, making conversation while cooking our savory crepes! The only thing is is the crepes are a decent size so maybe share one. They definitely kept us full throughout the day. Highly recommend this place!

Amazing! Savory crepe and then dessert crepe was the best meal I've had since we arrived. I had the ham and cheese with spinach and tomato; my hubby and daughter had salmon and son had tuna.  We each had different sweet crepes to finish the meal and they were equally good.  Everyone agreed it was delicious. The husband and wife team that made and served the food were absolutely wonderful! They were friendly and their recommendations were spot on. So pleased we found this place. Highly recommend.
My fiend &I find this crepe on the Yelp, that are so charmant, kindly and Gentile,Creps also are so tasty with the good presentation :-)
best crepe i've ever had! such lovely service too. it's a cool spot open late, i highly recommend!

DeliciousFillingFriendly Stray away from the mediocre crepe stands and get yourself to this cozy and super friendly restaurant tucked away from the touristy areas in the 20th.The crepes here are delicious with just the right amount of crisp. We had two savoury crepes and beer and it came to just around 15€. The staff is super friendly and attentive. You won't be disappointed.
Crepes are amazing at this place if you like crepes this is a must do place!!!A great hole in the wall find!!!The food and drinks are not expensive.

Wonderful people. They speak perfect English and serve their food with a smile. The crepes were wonderful and the beer was cold. If you are near this area you shouldn't miss this little cafe. We tried both the salmon and the jambon crepes and we really loved them. Honest food can't go wrong.

Little hole-in-a-wall place that is worth going to completely! Off the beaten path with some of the best crepes I've ever had and the only thing better is their service. So attentive and enthusiastically helpful, what a gem!

The crepes here were good but out of the way from where we stayed near the Eiffel Tower. I would recommend coming here during the day as the neighborhood is sketchy at night. The crepes are made fresh to order and it helps that the owner spoke English and was really nice and welcoming!
