One of my favourite things to do is food market shopping. This covered market is undiscovered gem. Maybe people do know a lot but far north of Paris I loved this place. Great produce. Practically everything you could want is here and it's laid out in an easy way with friendly staff and fresh produce. Perfect weekend visit.

My favorite thing to do on a Saturday morning in Paris:Wake up earlyGrab a canvas bagWalk towards 18eme smoking a cigarette Stop for coffee in a cafe on the Rue des AbbessesWander aimlessly around this covered marketAsk the vendors for as many "petits gouts" as I can stomachPurchase a hunk of cheese, a few slices of jambon de pays, and a small bottle of table winePick up a loaf of pain de campagne from one of the bakeries across the streetTrek up to the Sacre Coeur, preferably smoking another cigarettePark myself at the top of the stairs, or on a bench in the adjacent parkTear into my mini-picnic, while musing over the most beautiful views the city has to offerAbsolute heaven.

This covered market was one of the highlights of my trip to Paris. We picked up some extraordinary cheeses at the cheese market and wonderful sausage. The vendors were super helpful. On another day, we bought prepared foods to take back to our rental. Again, the vendor was incredibly helpful. This market gave me an opportunity to practice my French, something that can be difficult to do in Paris. Of note, I was the only one in my party who spoke French, and the others managed just fine. We visited several times during our week stay in the 18th arrondissement.

This is the farmers market you would want down the street from your home. Everything is there, the cheese, the bread, the poultry, pork, beef (all in separate stalls, of course) as well as the best artichokes, asparagus, melons, strawberries I've ever had. Do the farmers plant there seeds with sugar? Everything is so sweet, fresh and local.The yogurt was amazing. However, this is not the place to go if you want organic, or bio, which is how they refer to it here. I would shop around a bit for prices. One artichoke was 6EU another booth sold the for 2EU.

I went on a Saturday around 6:00, perhaps it was late and not many vendors were there but I found it a bit small. Prices were good, many vendors do not speak English. Fruits, veggies, cheeses, salamis, meat.

Lovely little market, with just enough choices, and very fairly priced. The space it's housed in is airy and light and the shop keepers are a delight. Most places accept credit card, but make sure to have some cash lying around.

I must confess, my friends and I only came here because we thought Saint Chapelle was in here as well. We saw the sign for the combo ticket and assumed they were in the same building. Saint Chapelle is right next door but we didn't realize that for quite a while, lol. HowEVER, it turned out to be quite fortuitous because the Palais, in its own right, is a very interesting place. It has more to do with its role in history (mostly the French Revolution) than any architectural feature, and I found it to be ultimately fascinating. You got to see what prison conditions were like during the revolution (minus the smells and blood, thank goodness), and its re-creation of Mario Antoinette's cell was quite eerie. There's a short film playing on loop in the museum that explains a lot about the Palais and its role in the Revolution that's worth watching. Best of all, after our visit we were able to get to the front of the line at Saint Chapelle with our combo ticket, so the hot tip is to buy the combo ticket at the Palais because there are no lines, then get to the front at the more popular Saint Chapelle.STEPH JUDGEMENT: Worth a visit if you're history buff; get the combo ticket with Saint Chapelle next door.

The Louvre is everything you would expect it to be.  Very crowded, vast and full of treasures.  If you are in Paris, you have to do it.  We paid for a private tour to see the highlights.  It is so large that you can spend days there if you want to see everything.
This is a beautiful addition to the Louvre grounds. A modern counter to the older architecture, it serves as a magnificent landmark.

The Louvre is one of the world's largest and most iconic museums, and its vast art collection is spectacular. Located in the heart of Paris, France, along the banks of the Seine River, this magnificent campus was once a royal palace. It's lovely, for sure!But is the time commitment and logistical hassle of seeing the Louvre worth it? Like any decision, it depends upon many factors, including your family's interests. You also need to consider your travel schedule, when you are visiting, and your willingness to endure a little stress in order to lock eyes with the Mona Lisa. I believe it's worth it. The architecture, culture, attention to details, artifacts, fossils, paintings and history is something you can't pass up.  Be sure to go early or on the later side because it gets really really busy.  There's so much to see other than paintings.  So take your time.

The coolest Pyramid around! (except for Egypt lol) The pyramid is beautiful! And it is huge. The architecture is just awesome to see. It is so pretty. Seeing the pyramid from the ground is cool, and it is also great to see it underneath the pyramid when you are inside. This structure was one of my favorites, aside from the L'Arc du Triomphe. The pyramid was my second favorite structural piece. You can see it right outside the Louvre. It is a masterpiece. Once you go underneath, where the entrance to the Louvre is, you can see the inside of the pyramid. It lets in lots of light and it sparkles in the reflection of the sun. Very pretty! It is a must see. I'm not sure if I liked seeing it from the outside more. Seeing it from the inside and looking up really made it look spectacular.
Loved the Louvre during the day and lit up at night. Took obligatory Louvre photos on the pillar blocks. Such a beautiful area to explore.

Even the pyramid gets it's own Yelp page, oh la la!Not totally surprising. The pyramid gets almost as much love as Mona (almost!) But really. Before entering into the museum, it's a must to get a picture with this beautiful, marvelous wonder first! Why do you think they have all those blocks set up around the perimeter? So you can get your iconic holding the Louvre in your hand photo or touching the tip. Top or bottom of the pyramid- your choice! The real wonder is getting to actual travel through the pyramid to get under ground to see all the fabulous art stored below!

Despite being to Paris, and more so the Louvre, the pyramid really didn't catch my attention until my latest trip.My first time at the Louvre all I could focus on was actually going in. Now that I had my second time there, the pyramid was much more interesting to me.For one thing, the Louvre was having issues selling tickets online, so you had to go through the pyramid to purchase tickets. For another, this landmark is huge and made of glass and metal.When you're trying to kill time or are just waiting to enter, believe me you notice it. That and it was during winter, so there were less people. At any rate, this pyramid is a beauty and I, of course, got my photo with it.

Once you enter the museum, go below the pyramid. The site from below is unbelievable. What a great design. The huge atrium is breathtaking. I purchased a tour and had a fantastic guide. This person had a masters in art history, which really showed during our tour. This person showed us the most important things in the museum. He called it the 3 divas of the Louvre. Venus de Milo, Winged Victory, and the Mona Lisa. They explained many bits of information on each of these most impressive sites. Things that you cannot know from just any tour book or even some guides. Undoubtedly this was the best tour I've ever had, and this location calls for it. We were told that if you spent 1 minute at every exhibit in this museum, it would take you over one month to see everything. What a great place this is. A place where history has stopped and tells you a story. The art is unbelievable. The status are amazing. The atmosphere is awe-inspiring. I absolutely loved the experience of being at the Louvre. Even with a map, you will be surprised at what you find around the next corner. You could spend a whole day here and go around the world and so far back in time that it doesn't seem real. I recommend getting a tour from a reputable company. It will make a huge difference in your experience.

Louvre is a beautiful place filled with artwork and collections from many different types of painters, sculptures, and much more to see if you are visiting here. This is one of the most iconic places that people all over the world would visit! This is my second time ever coming here and it still takes my breath away while I am walking all around the museum. Yes the line to get in is insane and they do make every single person go through security, so don't bring anything inside that could make you not get in! I would suggest coming here and spending a day walking around. I would say pick an early time slot but know you'll be having to wait a while to get in. Buy your tickets online and don't wait until you get there because they do sell out!

I've never really thought of the pyramid as it's own separate thing. It was just an unusual entrance to the museum. However, on further thought I can see it. It was a totally separate project by a well known artist.As pretty as it is outside, and it's a great known location to meet people, it's looking up from inside that really makes it.
Great service from the staff, escargot was excellent, people watching top notch. The serve Grimbergen Dubble which was a huge bonus. I'll be back!

I keep reading about good service and unfortunately my brother and I had terrible time with that. Waiter was rushing every moment of the conversation. I was brought the wrong starter, I didn't say anything because it was my second choice and I'd been walking all day so it was nice to finally eat something. Then I was almost brought the wrong meal, not sure how salmon was almost mistook for ribeye. Speaking of the food it was just alright and lacking flavor. I'd put it on par with an Applebees or Chilis in the states. I asked the waiter for a wine menu and I didn't get that until 20 minutes later, also in that time waiter took my water cup halfway through the meal and so I just drank out of the bottle at that point. By the time we got the menu my brother said he was good and he almost took it away, again acting too swiftly,  because I didn't get to say I'm the one who wanted wine.It was a Monday, and half the tables were open. I saw a table begging for someone to take their order, and eventually they asked for the manager. Saw a kid have to go to the table with the glassware to get a cup from the waiter. Not sure if terrible waiters or just a bad day, but they need to be more frequent at the tables, and slow down their time. Mistakes were made and this was very disappointing.

L'Europeen is a solid choice cafe among the many across Paris. I was here twenty years ago and several months ago this year and it delivers each time. It can be a busy place, but one is greeted in the customary French manner and you can opt for indoor seating when the weather is not cooperating, as it has been each time I have been here. It is  conveniently located across from Gare de Lyon and the nearby tube station. Given I had just arrived from CDG and had not checked into my hotel, they were accommodating and well prepared to check my bags at the desk, which seems a regular thing across from the train station.The specials are quite the value proposition. I chose the oysters as an appetizer and flank steak with shallots as the entree. My total, including beer, was less than thirty Euros. The oysters were fresh, served simply with lemons on the half shell with the brine retained. The flank steak was cooked to medium rare temperature that managed a slight crust without grilling. Simple pleasures.The menu is extensive and pay attention to the specials. It's hard to go wrong with whatever you order. Four stars.

Decided to try this place since it's close to the train station. Was very disappointed in the onion soup. Cheese is okay, but the soup itself is very bland, compared to what I have in the US. I need to try more place to see if this is how it suppose to be or what, but so far I don't like it. The bulot is good but might have upset my stomach a little bit after; the sauce is a little too garlic-y on its own but matches well with the food. Service is super slow, but I think it's just how it is here.
Walked in and ate at the bar. Everything was wonderful. Great service and impeccably prepared food. Service was astute and the décor was a look back at opulence.

Fresh seafood and good service!  I opted for the cold seafood platter came with 6 oysters, 2 prawns, mussels & clams for €28 was very good! My hubby got the sea bass €26 and onion soup for €9, wines were €9-18 a glass!Bordeaux wine was excellent and the chocolate ice cream was definitely made of cacao and lots of it!

This was my go to fine dining restaurant in Paris. So much so, I had to eat here twice. It's located right across the street from the train station. Nice ambience, good tasting food, and excellent service.  Didn't notice any indoor smoking. When you walk in, you must show your covid vaccination passport/card to the lovely hostess. Had the hanger steak both times, with a side of green beans the first time and a side of fries on the second visit. Had to order the crème brûlée for dessert on both occasions.  It's a fairly large sized crème brûlée, but consumed it all, of course.

Had an amazing time at L'Européen. The service was equally amazing to our meal. The ambiance was calm and Beautiful. The décor made the restaurant elegant for a couples to fall in love. L'Européen, merci beaucoup pour cette belle soirée.

This is one of my favorite restaurants in Paris. What this restaurant offers is a very upscale dining environment yet very accessible to all customers. This restaurant has a very good menu. The food they offer here is based on French cuisine. Every meal I have ever eaten here is well-prepared with a very nice presentation. They also offer a very good drink menu with a large selection of wine.In terms of interior design, this restaurant has its primary dining area plus a very nice bar area. When you enter, the host or hostess will ask you if you have come in for a meal or simply drinks and they will then seat you in the appropriate section.The staff here are all very nice and very friendly. Though this restaurant tends to get crowded in the evening, and the staff may become a bit busy, they always take very good care of their customers.One of the interesting things about this restaurant is that, due to the fact that it is across the street from the train station, a good percentage of the clientele will enter with their suitcases in tow.  This is not a problem, it is just something that is unique and a bit different from your average up-scale Paris restaurant. Overall, great place to eat and/or have a drink.
Food was very good. Had the salmon and wine and I enjoyed it. Many seafood items but they have a kids menu. Great family place and large parties. Very helpful.
What a huge mall underground! There's shop after shop after shop from Zara to H&M. There are restrooms that cost one Euro on the bottom level.

Located within walking distance of the Louvre, the Westfield Forum is built on the site of the Halls old french fresh market.  It is now an indoor mall, mostly underground, with the typical clothing stores found in any mall.  It is connected to a busy Metro line, so has easy access from around the city.  Decided to stop by before our Louvre tour....ended up not spending that much time since it really isn't that unique.  One can try to get wifi by signing up for the Westfield loyalty club, but couldn't get it to work.
Worst mall experience ever. Confusing, hot, swarms of people. Incredibly noisy. Bathrooms were very clean and quiet. But that's it.

I haven't visited this shopping center in almost a decade but we came through here and walked around a bit.  It was clean and seemed fairly updated.  There were the usual stores you would expect, plus a good number of independent boutique shops.  Fun place to kill some time.The location itself is above a subway hub, so it's really easy to get to.  It is quite a maze to get through.  If you're going to the surface, be aware you're taking the right exit.  It'll avoid confusion and save you a lot of time.The subway station below is also where you can take RER B to the airport in case you needed to do some last minute shopping.

The Forum des Halles has evolved a lot in recent years, and I say this after visiting this place more than 9 years ago. Initially, the general state of that place left something to be desired, but they have managed to make it a beautiful space not only dedicated to shopping.The Forum des Halles is just a few blocks away from the Marais (gay village) or the awesome Georges Pompidou Center and is located above the Chatelet-les-Halles metro station, which makes it a very busy spot. You will find some well-known brands such as Zara, H & M, Comptoirs des Cotonniers, Promod, Etam, Monoprix and the Fnac.I recommend this place if you're in an affordable shopping mood while visiting the heart of Paris!

One of the best and largest shopping centres in France, it is modern in the Les Halles area (previously Paris' central fresh food market until demolished in 1971)I like the square and overall shopping centre, the fact it is built mainly underground and links into Paris' transport network is also impressive while still retaining phone good signal, it is modern and rather impressive.I didn't like the entrance into the shopping centre, there was only one lift working which seemed like I was entering a metro station, it smelt a little funny and wasn't clean, going from there into the shopping centre felt like night and day.It has impressive sculpture throughout and they are currently doing a lot to help keep shoppers safe such as by enforcing a one-way system. The mall security seemed friendly and happy to point me in the right direction of a nice Starbucks store.The whole area has been transformed really well, I do feel the current listing on Yelp is a little unfair as it seems to include Les Halles as an area as a whole, rather than Westfield here who deserve credit for rescuing a hole in the ground.If you're looking for somewhere indoors to shop in Paris, this is the place for you, while this is far from the best or biggest mall's I've been too, there's just something about this place I really like and it could just be my favourite shopping centre which doesn't have an Apple Store.

Good selection of stores and shops that is located in a busy area. They have your regulars such as Zara and Nike and H & M but you also find some unique boutiques. You can spend an afternoon walking around as it is quite large and you can also find a place for a treat if your so inclined. Overall just an average shopping mall that gets crowded with a good selection of shops and food.

It used to be an outdoor market now a shopping mall with subway station. A large Lego store on the ground floor. I like the furniture store the 'Maisons Du Monde' . Chained coffee shop 'Paul' is also good too.

I've heard people describe this place as hole in the ground, it is a very apt description - considering the following factors - they are right now under very massive renovation and the fact that it currently is sitting on top of a major hub of transportation for the Paris Metro/RER lines. - Think the underbelly of Union Station in Toronto, only bigger & dirtier and without the old building train station feel.Most of the retail stores are mainstream, like H&M and FNAC, so in other words nothing to write home about.  There is a nice furniture store on one of the upper levels; but I find that street browsing at the stores that don't belong to the Mall at street level are much more intriguing and much more lively

This shopping center is completely under construction right now, so many of the stores are closed or hard to get to.  It was hard to navigate around this shopping center because there was no standard walking path.  It seemed to branch out in every direction.  It has all the standard stores like H&M and other chain stores.  Nothing special as far as I'm concerned.

A great way to see a ton of Dali's sculptures in depth. They have more than just his sculptures of course, but they seem to be the central theme.  While they did not offer an audio tour, all the pieces have descriptions by them for you to read.  Certainly a must do for Dali lovers, however, I am not sure its a must do for anyone else.You'll probably spent about 30-45 minutes with ease.  Connected to the museum is a small gallery where you can purchase his work or work by other artists inspired by Dali. We went during a weekday and had no problem walking up and purchasing tickets, however, I believe they sell them in advance on-line and that might be worth doing to avoid issues.

This was a nice surprise due toSmall sign directing us. We had not planned on this. This is about Dali sculptures and there aren't that many. This will make you think about him. Small exhibition, 2 floors.
This museum made me start to dislike Dalí...Tiny museum worth nowhere NEAR the price of admission. Man working there was super rude to us. Felt kind of cheated at the end.

Find that friend who loves  different art than you.  Near Sacré-Cœur is a Dalí museum and gallery. 12€ to wander the couple of floors at your own leisure. There is plenty of piece descriptions and history notes throughout- written in both French and English. I knew the name, but had no idea his history or his range in art materials. The gallery had so many sizes of paintings and sketches. The sculptures  were amazing, some with beautiful soft details, while others made you cock your head to really make sureyou saw what you thought you were seeing.  The colors!!!   The themes.  An hour plus well spent.  Easiest to walk to, follow the signs. Parking is limited and the streets  to it are narrow.

Abbesses may be the closest Metro stop, but it is the epitome of hell unless you love, need and want a stair master workout on steroids. Just to get out of the metro station, you have to go up a small winding staircase for what seems like 5 or 6 flights of stairs. Once you have made it out, you still have to climb the Montmartre hill and even more stairs. I would recommend exiting the Anvers Metro stop and taking the Funicular to the top of the hill to Sacre Coeur and then walking down hill to Espace Dali. It will take longer, but it will be much gentler on your feet and your heart. Espace Dali has an audio guide for €3. You will need to leave your ID or passport in order to use the device. The staff will return your identification as long as you return the device. The audio guide is worth it because it explains why Dali uses certain symbols (crutches, drawers, melting time pieces, etc.) in his pieces. It also talks about the artist, his life and his influence on art and society at the time he was alive.  Do notice that you pickup the audio guide on the top floor when you buy your ticket and enter the museum. You the proceed downstairs to the gallery.  After your visit, you will work your way back upstairs through the gallery store and leave the building. As you walk outside, you will pass the entrance. The entrance is the same place where you return your audio guide and collect your identification, but you will actually have to leave the museum and return to the entrance to do this. Because Dali's pieces are so unusual and have so much symbolism, you really should get the audio device. It makes the visit worthwhile. This is my second time to this museum, and I still find his work  and thought process intriguing. It seems like a lot of his work is actually for sale in the store gallery as well as art galleries in Paris too. Dali is no longer living, so a purchase of his work will be a last of it's kind.

A small 2 floors museum in Montmartre. Salvador Dalí is known for the melting clock. His museum is another tourist attraction place to see. There are not a lot of art works here to see. I am guessing it is not as big as the Salvador Dalí museum in Florida either. Admission is inexpensive. Note that some of his artwork are for sales and can be purchased. Most of them are just replicas.
If you're in Paris I definitely recommend going to Montmartre and visiting the Dali museum. They did a really good job storytelling Dali's work and life. Definitely worth the time!

I'm not really sure about this place because in one sense it is a museum that is dedicated to the works of Salvador Dali, but on the other hand you have the opportunity to actually purchase some of his works. In fact the suggestion is that you might even be able to purchase some of the really expensive works if the offers for private consultations are anything to go by. However, I didn't come here to purchase any art, I came here to check out some of Dali's works, and there is certainly an interesting collection here. Mind you, I wouldn't expect anything really famous, namely because they happen to be in the big name galleries. Worth checking out if you are in the area though.

Eeeeeek.... "insert heart eyes here"We purchased our tickets online in advance for a specific time. So we didn't have to deal with anything upon arrival. Literally showed them our tickets, and BOOM we were in!This is a very small gallery with some really fantastic pieces. SO WORTH IT. There is also a small gift shop that has some great items.Definitely worth the visit if you are a Dali fan!

An amazing way to spend your day! We have a Dali museum near by in St. Pete and I'm so ashamed to say it's always been on my list but I've never gone. After visiting the Espace Dali i am so inspired and will definitely be visiting the next museum. I saw people with audio guides how every all signs and information was in French and English. I learned so much  about Dali and his art. I never realized how deeply religious he was and how it influenced his art. Lots of original pieces and art by Dali that i had never seen before. You can easily get lost and spend 2-3 hours in here and it's not that big.... just that deep

Drafted in 2019, decided to post for future reference:This was my favorite farmer's market in Paris. Tons of fresh fish, meat (both raw and prepared), cheese, and many fruit stalls. I especially loved the prepared meat in the stall near the entrance (they have many prepared items to choose from--I ended up loving the duck foie gras and duck rillette). Also, people were helpful and willing to deal with my poor French :)As another reviewer mentioned, there aren't many (perhaps any) ready-to-way meals. But I wasn't looking for that, and I found the quality to be fantastic.

I always love to see the market when I'm traveling. It's might be the best way to get away from the tourist crowd and get a more local feel to things. In the 12th Arrondissement is Marché d'Aligre which is a small market that has butcher shops, fish mongers, fruits and vegetables, and flowers. I'd recommend anyone in the area to check this place out, even for a short walkthrough.

I wanted to experience a local French farmer's market and I'm glad I came across this last minute. We walked the 40 minutes (we had a wonderfully decadent breakfast and needed to walk some of it off) to the market and I was hoping it would be worth it. As you get to the neighborhood, you start seeing signs, so I knew we were on the right track. We went on a Tuesday at around 10:30 am or so. There appeared to be several areas: covered featuring stalls specializing in cheese, meats, etc. A majority of them appeared to still be closed for their August vacation. The street to the side were the stalls from fresh seasonal produce like mushrooms, lettuce, tomatoes, potatoes, plums, peaches, and herbs. A lot of the stalls sell similar things so go around and "shop" if you can. A majority of them put up the prices so you can compare. Some stalls have "do not touch" signs where they pack the produce for you. There's also a flea market section as well. Most all of the produce looked delicious and they weren't all that expensive - some even cheaper than back in the States. We ended up getting a small eggplant, a kilogram of yellow plums for €0.99, and a carton of cute little strawberries. The plums were quite good and the strawberries were as well. The shoppers appear to be mainly locals but the shop owners seem to know other languages as well (I was arigatou-ed before we told him English would be fine). I can't comment much on the covered portion of the market (we're vegetarian and on top of that, most cheeses in France aren't vegetarian, especially at fromageries - I've asked because I love cheese) or the flea market because we had to walk back before our fruit decided to die under the midday sun.What you need to know: try to go early for best picks, shop around, they seem to be cash only, go here if you have a kitchen on hand (we did) to get some good produce and prepare a cheap meal. Definitely recommended if you have time!

One of the best markets in Paris when you include the extensive outdoor portion that extends for a couple blocks on either side of the indoor market. Great coffee places along the street too for that post market pick me up. Inside find great selection of cheese and locally made craft beers, along with the usual meat selection. Outside are many fruit and vegetable vendors. Go before noon for the best selections. some vendors are not open after lunch.

This was the second of the two markers we visited in Paris. It says 'covered' but only about a third of the space was. Under the covered area houses a large rotisserie with a beautiful suckling pig, a large cheese shop, deli offerings, and some international eateries. Everything smelled amazing. Outside, there was lots of fresh produce and vintage, used clothing and other goods. Save some room in your stomach for this place, and heads up, decisions on which place to get your food will not be easy!

We arrived at 4:18pm Wednesday on a 98 degree day.  I thought there might be outdoor and indoor vendors but there were only indoor vendors. Fish looked good as did cheeses and fruits but prices were the same as the vendors on Saint Antoine.  So our driver from cdg who said prices and the experience was worth it was wrong.  Maybe it was the heat but very few vendors and the pictures shown were not representative of my experience.

Fantastic market! Great selection of meats, cheeses, seafood, and prepared foods. We picked up some cured meat and a slice of head cheese for a very reasonable price. Both were savory and fatty. The vendor was in the north west section of the market.

Great place to shop and vendors are really friendly, my husband and I woke up really early and was there by 7 am but most vendors were still setting up. Perhaps it would have been best after 10 am and see everything

One of the best markets I visited in Paris. Lots of great vendors of meats (obviously), cheeses (obviously), and fish. All of the vendors seemed special in their own way. Great location, I would definitely recommend coming here. Also, on certain days there is an outdoor market too with endless produce vendors and flea market vendors too.

This market is excellent. I do not really see a reason to go to any other markets in Paris because this place (almost) has it all. Ok, if you are going to eat stuff or to buy snack food like saucisson or cheese, there are probably better spots. Personally, after spending every other weekend in Lyon for a year, I cannot get over how amazing their market is along the river on Sundays - and such prices... But I digress! :DAnyways, there are tons of stands for veggies of all kinds and the choices are much better than your typical street markets in Paris. I live in the 18th and I still come over to Aligre to shop for fruits and veggies on Sundays because their bio stands are so cheap and because around the market you can get anything else you need to cook up your dreams. Often there are deals for like 4 kg of fruits and veggies for 10 euros or there abouts. Then, as the day goes on, the deals get even better - especially around 1pm (but be careful, in hot months the produce is going for cheap because it has gotten baked by the sun so it might be worth to pay more earlier). The other day I got 5 limes for 2 euros (where they are normally 80 cents in the supermarket) and 2 bags with 8 portobello mushrooms each for a total of....2 EUROS!!! GO TO ALIGRE!!!
Husband and I are staying close by and decided to give this place a shot. One of the waitresses spoke english and was very helpful. The service was quick and the food was delicious!

Le Baribal was conveniently located near where we stayed and was thus an easy pick for dinner when my friends and I got too lazy to venture further. Like most European restaurants, service was attentive and the place was cozy, modern, and brightly lit. All I had was a burger patty topped with an egg and complemented with egg pasta that was all a bit bland although not terrible. It helped that the portion was generous.It may be unfair for me to judge this place without giving it another shot but I don't think I'll be there anytime soon.

We were near Montparnasse and wanted a simple dinner, so we came here. It's a very no frills place. It started out stuffy indoors (typical for Paris), but eventually they turned on the AC, which helped. Wines are cheap. The 25 cl and 50 cl options are a better value than the glasses. I had a cote du Rhône villages and a cote du bourge, both of which were ok, but at their prices, you can't really complain. Food - - Crudite: shredded carrots, shredded celery root, tomatoes, cucumbers, and diced beets - they ended up putting a creamy white dressing on it. Had I known, I would have asked for it on the side - Jambon de Bayonne: good jam, accompanied by pickles. Their baguette was just ok - Steak tartare: you can have it prepared or DIY, which is what I chose. It comes with pickles, red onions, herbs, an egg yolk in its shell, and various sauces like a really good mustard, ketchup, worchestire sauce, salt, pepper, olive oil. I got it with a side of fries, which reminded me of McDonald's fries (good in my opinion) - Duck confit: you get your choice of vegetables , but they recommended the potatoes, which was the right choice Overall, it was quite filling and a very simple classic French bistro meal. I wouldn't call it a destination, per se, but if you're looking for a simple dinner in the neighborhood, it's fine.

This place was opened late. We came here for late night eating. It's pretty good. I ordered the duck and it was good. I also ordered the floating dessert. It was good.Food:Chard confit: really good. Bread: deliciousService: in the beginning they thought we were French because I spoke French to them and so they were really nice... Them my husband opened his mouth and... No.... That all changed. They didn't really care for us afterward.Ambiance:QuaintOverall: open late. Good for late eating
Very authentic French food.. Steak and dauphinoughe was so delicious. Very reasonably priced too, would definitely recommend
It's pretty good here. The servers were very friendly. I ordered smoked salmon appetizer for my dinner and it was really good.
This place is in a convenient location to where my hotel was, the duck was really tasty, the servers were extremely helpful with making menu suggestions and service.

I grew up in the 15th.  There used to be a fair amount of solid casual joints.  Now most of the places are gone.  There's some that have redesigned their spaces and "modernized" the place.  Added a bunch of hipster items.  I guess that's necessary at some level.  The Baribal still serves many of the same items as I ate since the 80's.   Still solid.  Harder and harder to find.

Le Baribal is located in a lively part of town, and it has the local vibe such that it won't be on anyone's list when they're planning a trip to Paris. Nonetheless, somebody I knew in the city took me here and I thought it was a pretty good meal.We both went for the steak, and I was quite amazed at the sheer size of the portions. The steak was cooked to a medium rare per my request, and I thought the taste of the meat really shined through and did not get cheapened by too much seasoning or sauce.I was a fan of the wine they had recommended, and at the end of dinner we enjoyed various types of cheeses from their cutting board. I thoroughly enjoyed the dining experience, as it was quite a change from the types of dining that I had been having all trip long. The prices were quite good as well, and I'd most happily return here if I'm in the area again.

I've been here countless times and I cannot remember ever having a bad meal. I love their rabbit rillette, crudités, tomatoes, celeriac, and country pâté as starters. They're all delicious. The magret de canard is phenomenal and always cooked a perfect medium. Sometimes I just want a lovely salad and their frisée with lardons and egg is somewhat addictive. In the winter when I want a heavy meal the veal medallions with Roquefort sauce is insane. They also have a delightful salmon filet that seems like it's flattened and pan fried, served with lemon butter.It's sooooo good. As to sides,  I LOVE the sardelaise potatoes, which are fried potatoes with trumpet mushrooms. The portion is huge and I always ask if I can have half potatoes and half spinach. They're always accommodating. I never have dessert but I've seen some good looking ones walk by. I really enjoy this bistro, as you can tell by how many items I've eaten, because it's unassuming and just good, correct French food.

An adorable cafe that was my very first stop on my first visit to Paris. The waiters were absolutely delightful and very friendly to my friend and I. Since it was All Saint's Day, we didn't have too many options for breakfast cafes as our flight had arrived early that morning, but La Pointe was open and classically French.I ordered a croissant with hot chocolate and my friend ordered a coffee with an assortment of other breads. This cafe is in a convenient location hear Les Halles and has a pretty vast menu for lunch and dinner as well.
Good little cafe, friendly staff, lots of seating.  Good spot to hit up after les halles mall.

This is a decent spot for sitting, having some wine or cappuccino, and people watching at the edge of Rue Montorgueil and near the exit of Les Halles.My husband would decidedly give it 5 stars b/c his salad du jour (which was delicious fatty duck with a very pungent cheese and light dressing) was fantastic and, according to him, the best salad he's ever had :)My foie gras pate, however, was really not nearly one of the best I've ever had, so that brings this place to 3 stars for me.   I'm sure there is a lot of great food on their menu, I just didn't get a chance to give it another go.However, for relaxing in the afternoon, excellent people watching, and clearly fantastic salads, this place is a sure bet!

I've often gone to Jet Lag, which is the cafe on both sides of this - but this is more convenient for meeting friends as you don't have to figure out which side of Jet Lag they are in.  Friendly service.

We had nice dinner on a cold December 14, 2018 night in ParisWe (my lovely wife and I) had a chicken stuffed with mushroom and my daughter had a "ravioli" Both were excellent the service was great, the waitress spoke English and was very nice and the food was served quickly

This is the quintessential French restaurant you need to visit, but more so, you also need to check out Rue Montorgueil just east of here.  If you're not in the mood for a big meal, head down Rue Montorgueil and pickup some gelato, cookies, and/or pastries.

I'll give this two stars because the wine was tasty and the location was convenient, but the service was AWFUL.  The waiter acted as though it was painful for him to wait on us and never even asked whether we wanted dinner (we did). So I paid my check and another, more deserving business gotmy money.

La Pointe is a great place to sit and people watch while you enjoy good food and drink.  We ventured out and found this local gem for lunch. We ordered the Mix Plate and the honey and milk custard dessert with red fruit. The Mix plate was an amazing combination of cold meats and cheeses with a light salad. This became our go to lunch order and La Pointe had the best plate out of all the places we encountered. The dessert was a light milk and honey custard that was refreshing and topped off our meal perfectly.After a few days and two disappointing dinners (one down the street from La Pointe), we decided to go for the sure thing and have dinner here as well. We arrived to breakdancers performing in the street just out side of the restaurant, so we were entertained as the super friendly hostess and waitress seated us. We asked what the best dishes were and she recommended the steak. He had a beef kabob and I had the steak frites. Both were delicious and well cooked. My steak was similar to a hangar or flank steak cut cooked to a juicy medium rare. The frites were perfectly crispy on the outside and soft in the middle. No soggy fries here (see my review for L'Epicerie down the street). The steak came with an amazing pepper hollandaise that was addictive. The Pink Pimp cocktail I ordered was perfectly crafted and he ordered the local beer. The creme brûlée dessert was so decadent, I felt I needed a glass of red wine after we walked home. It had a perfect candy crust on top of sinfully creamy smooth goodness. I want some now as I write this.

name: Créteil Soleil
address: Avenue de la France Libre 94012 Créteil France

reviews.review: Really nice mall with a ton of selection. Check out all the restaurants in the food court.

This shopping mall is vast and has all the brand you could think of commonly. There is a big food court that has many selections that are unique and restaurant like and not just a typical McDonalds or Burger King type of food court. The mall closes early but the restaurants were still open for business for a couple of hours longer. The bathrooms were a bit limited and stretched far across the mall so getting to one takes a bit of time. Overall a nice place to shop and eat.
Its the best mall in Paris. Has all the major brands. The food court is awesome. It gets too crowded on Saturdays but on weekdays, its too much fun! Recommend it to Parisians as well as tourists.

RECOMMENDED FOR:~Art lovers~Fountain lovers~Fans of Niki de Saint Phalle~Those looking for the lesser known sites of ParisI'm a big fan of Niki de Saint Phalle and so of course, this was a must see on my quickie three day weekend in Paris last weekend!  I had seen video of it being created and was really excited.  We made it there and spent some time taking photos and videos and the sculptures are gorgeous, of course.  I believe there is supposed to be some additional movement but I could be wrong and maybe it is just the water spray from them.  Regardless, they were lovely to look at and I was very happy to have had the opportunity to go take a peek at Niki's art.  She was such a gem.If you're a fan, you can see her work in Escondido, California at Queen Calafia's Magic Circle Garden and about an hour north of Rome in Italy at the Tarot Garden.  Her work is intense and amazing.

My second favorite (equally favorite, mind you) fountain in Paris has to be La Fountaine Stravinsky. Not just because of cultural roots connection, but also because of my love of modern art and all aspects of it.First of all, it just next to Centre Pompidou - win!Second, there is a little cart on the corner that sells best panini you would ever eat in your life (I assure you they quite different from American variations and drool-worthy-finger-licking-delicious!). Thirdly, it is just most fascinating fountain to watch! So, you got that panini, right? Now just plop on the seat along the edge of the fountain, get comfortable, watch and listen. 16 bright whimsical kinetic sculptures rotate, spew water or just look back at you... Water splashing, pouring, spouting. People of all origins chatting around. All in movement, all rotating, going somewhere, never stopping...It's my favorite spot to spend lunch time in summer, in Paris, hands down.
Right next to the Pompidou Centre. Love the mermaid :)

name: Hôtel de Ville
address: 1 place de la République 92300 Levallois Perret France

reviews.review: Superb building that stands on its place and which airs castle city. It must be said that City Hall Levallois-Perret, built at the end of Nineteenth century as much, has a style unique to this era: high roofing slates, a wide porch, topped by a lantern which dominates the clock. We find this style easily recognizable in Paris, Vannes, Neuilly, and so on. But the time the building was also the time of emancipation and the struggle to establish itself facing the powerful neighbours Clichy and Neuilly. So Mayor of the time, Trébois commanded a majestic City Hall, size much more important. As for his lavish ornaments, there is a style Louis XIV very present. Within you will see that everything is monumental: a grand double staircase revolution that leads to the Salons d'Honneur, long forty-four meters, decorated sumptuous frescoes painted at different times and lit by twelve beautiful chandeliers, a room richly decorated Council and having the particularity to own forums in height to accommodate a wide public. The hall marriages added belatedly by the current mayor (elected in 1983) is magnificent, in the style candy box! A visit to the castle before or after the castles of the Loire!
